ğŸ’» Day 46: Throw Example in Java ğŸ§¬ğŸ”„ What You Explored: âœ… The concept of using the throw keyword to explicitly throw exceptions in Java. âœ… How to create custom error messages when throwing exceptions to handle specific conditions in your code. âœ… A real-world example of throwing an exception when an invalid input is provided, such as when checking a person's age and ensuring it meets a certain criteria (e.g., age should be 18 or older).ğŸ”¥ Why It Matters: Using the throw keyword helps enforce rules and conditions in your code. When certain conditions are not met (like an invalid age), you can trigger an exception, allowing you to handle these errors appropriately. It adds a layer of control and error management to your program, making it more robust and predictable.ğŸ† What You Practiced: âœ” Explicitly throwing exceptions using the throw keyword in response to invalid conditions. âœ” Creating custom exception messages to provide more meaningful feedback when an error occurs. âœ” Demonstrating how throwing an exception can stop the normal flow of execution and how you can handle errors by throwing exceptions deliberately. âœ” Understanding the role of exceptions in ensuring your program adheres to specific rules and logic (e.g., age validation).Jain (Deemed-to-be University)Dr. Sanjeev Kumar Mandal, Ph.D, M.C.A, B.C.ADr Sagar Gulati

ğŸ’» Day 46: Throw Example in Java ğŸ§¬ğŸ”„ What You Explored: âœ… The concept of using the throw keyword to explicitly throw exceptions in Java. âœ… How to create custom error messages when throwing exceptions to handle specific conditions in your code. âœ… A real-world example of throwing an exception when an invalid input is provided, such as when checking a person's age and ensuring it meets a certain criteria (e.g., age should be 18 or older).ğŸ”¥ Why It Matters: Using the throw keyword helps enforce rules and conditions in your code. When certain conditions are not met (like an invalid age), you can trigger an exception, allowing you to handle these errors appropriately. It adds a layer of control and error management to your program, making it more robust and predictable.ğŸ† What You Practiced: âœ” Explicitly throwing exceptions using the throw keyword in response to invalid conditions. âœ” Creating custom exception messages to provide more meaningful feedback when an error occurs. âœ” Demonstrating how throwing an exception can stop the normal flow of execution and how you can handle errors by throwing exceptions deliberately. âœ” Understanding the role of exceptions in ensuring your program adheres to specific rules and logic (e.g., age validation).Jain (Deemed-to-be University)Dr. Sanjeev Kumar Mandal, Ph.D, M.C.A, B.C.ADr Sagar Gulati

ğŸ’» Day 45: Method Overloading in SimpleMath ğŸ§¬ğŸ”„ What You Explored: âœ… The concept of method overloading, where you define multiple methods with the same name but different parameter types or number of parameters within the same class. âœ… How method overloading allows the same operation to be performed on different data types (e.g., int vs. double), providing flexibility and readability in the code. âœ… Real-world example of method overloading (e.g., a SimpleMath class with overloaded add(), sub(), and div() methods to handle both integer and floating-point numbers).ğŸ”¥ Why It Matters: Method overloading improves the versatility of your methods and makes your code more intuitive. Instead of creating multiple method names for similar operations, you can use the same method name with different parameters, keeping your code cleaner and easier to maintain. It helps you handle multiple scenarios with a single logical method name.ğŸ† What You Practiced: âœ” Creating overloaded methods with the same name but different parameter types (e.g., int vs. double). âœ” Understanding how Java resolves method calls based on the number and type of arguments passed. âœ” Demonstrating method overloading with arithmetic operations like addition, subtraction, and division. âœ” Calling overloaded methods with different argument types and observing the results.Jain (Deemed-to-be University) Dr. Sanjeev Kumar Mandal, Ph.D, M.C.A, B.C.A Dr Sagar Gulati

ğŸ’» Day 45: Method Overloading in SimpleMath ğŸ§¬ğŸ”„ What You Explored: âœ… The concept of method overloading, where you define multiple methods with the same name but different parameter types or number of parameters within the same class. âœ… How method overloading allows the same operation to be performed on different data types (e.g., int vs. double), providing flexibility and readability in the code. âœ… Real-world example of method overloading (e.g., a SimpleMath class with overloaded add(), sub(), and div() methods to handle both integer and floating-point numbers).ğŸ”¥ Why It Matters: Method overloading improves the versatility of your methods and makes your code more intuitive. Instead of creating multiple method names for similar operations, you can use the same method name with different parameters, keeping your code cleaner and easier to maintain. It helps you handle multiple scenarios with a single logical method name.ğŸ† What You Practiced: âœ” Creating overloaded methods with the same name but different parameter types (e.g., int vs. double). âœ” Understanding how Java resolves method calls based on the number and type of arguments passed. âœ” Demonstrating method overloading with arithmetic operations like addition, subtraction, and division. âœ” Calling overloaded methods with different argument types and observing the results.Jain (Deemed-to-be University) Dr. Sanjeev Kumar Mandal, Ph.D, M.C.A, B.C.A Dr Sagar Gulati

ğŸ’» Day 45: Method Overloading in SimpleMath ğŸ§¬ğŸ”„ What You Explored: âœ… The concept of method overloading, where you define multiple methods with the same name but different parameter types or number of parameters within the same class. âœ… How method overloading allows the same operation to be performed on different data types (e.g., int vs. double), providing flexibility and readability in the code. âœ… Real-world example of method overloading (e.g., a SimpleMath class with overloaded add(), sub(), and div() methods to handle both integer and floating-point numbers).ğŸ”¥ Why It Matters: Method overloading improves the versatility of your methods and makes your code more intuitive. Instead of creating multiple method names for similar operations, you can use the same method name with different parameters, keeping your code cleaner and easier to maintain. It helps you handle multiple scenarios with a single logical method name.ğŸ† What You Practiced: âœ” Creating overloaded methods with the same name but different parameter types (e.g., int vs. double). âœ” Understanding how Java resolves method calls based on the number and type of arguments passed. âœ” Demonstrating method overloading with arithmetic operations like addition, subtraction, and division. âœ” Calling overloaded methods with different argument types and observing the results.Jain (Deemed-to-be University) Dr. Sanjeev Kumar Mandal, Ph.D, M.C.A, B.C.A Dr Sagar Gulati

ğŸ’» Day 44: Multilevel Inheritance in Java (Grandparent â†’ Parent â†’ Child) ğŸ§¬ğŸ”„ What You Explored: âœ… The concept of multilevel inheritance, where a class (Child) inherits from another class (Parent), and that class (Parent) inherits from a third class (Grandparent). âœ… How multilevel inheritance creates a chain of class relationships, allowing subclasses to inherit behavior from multiple levels of the class hierarchy. âœ… Real-world example of multilevel inheritance (e.g., a Grandparent class, a Parent class, and a Child class, where the child inherits behavior from both the parent and the grandparent).ğŸ”¥ Why It Matters: Multilevel inheritance enables you to build more complex hierarchies of classes, allowing for a more structured and reusable design. It encourages the reuse of code at each level of the hierarchy while also enabling specialization and extension of functionality in subclasses. This makes the code more organized, easier to maintain, and scalable.ğŸ† What You Practiced: âœ” Creating a class hierarchy where a subclass inherits from another subclass (Grandparent â†’ Parent â†’ Child). âœ” Understanding how each subclass can access properties and methods of its parent and grandparent classes. âœ” Demonstrating method inheritance and overriding in a multilevel context (e.g., showGrandparent(), showParent(), showChild()). âœ” Understanding how Java resolves method calls through the chain of inheritance.Jain (Deemed-to-be University)Dr. Sanjeev Kumar Mandal, Ph.D, M.C.A, B.C.ADr Sagar Gulati

ğŸ’» Day 45: Method Overloading in SimpleMath ğŸ§¬ğŸ”„ What You Explored: âœ… The concept of method overloading, where you define multiple methods with the same name but different parameter types or number of parameters within the same class. âœ… How method overloading allows the same operation to be performed on different data types (e.g., int vs. double), providing flexibility and readability in the code. âœ… Real-world example of method overloading (e.g., a SimpleMath class with overloaded add(), sub(), and div() methods to handle both integer and floating-point numbers).ğŸ”¥ Why It Matters: Method overloading improves the versatility of your methods and makes your code more intuitive. Instead of creating multiple method names for similar operations, you can use the same method name with different parameters, keeping your code cleaner and easier to maintain. It helps you handle multiple scenarios with a single logical method name.ğŸ† What You Practiced: âœ” Creating overloaded methods with the same name but different parameter types (e.g., int vs. double). âœ” Understanding how Java resolves method calls based on the number and type of arguments passed. âœ” Demonstrating method overloading with arithmetic operations like addition, subtraction, and division. âœ” Calling overloaded methods with different argument types and observing the results.Jain (Deemed-to-be University) Dr. Sanjeev Kumar Mandal, Ph.D, M.C.A, B.C.A Dr Sagar Gulati

ğŸ’» Day 44: Multilevel Inheritance in Java (Grandparent â†’ Parent â†’ Child) ğŸ§¬ğŸ”„ What You Explored: âœ… The concept of multilevel inheritance, where a class (Child) inherits from another class (Parent), and that class (Parent) inherits from a third class (Grandparent). âœ… How multilevel inheritance creates a chain of class relationships, allowing subclasses to inherit behavior from multiple levels of the class hierarchy. âœ… Real-world example of multilevel inheritance (e.g., a Grandparent class, a Parent class, and a Child class, where the child inherits behavior from both the parent and the grandparent).ğŸ”¥ Why It Matters: Multilevel inheritance enables you to build more complex hierarchies of classes, allowing for a more structured and reusable design. It encourages the reuse of code at each level of the hierarchy while also enabling specialization and extension of functionality in subclasses. This makes the code more organized, easier to maintain, and scalable.ğŸ† What You Practiced: âœ” Creating a class hierarchy where a subclass inherits from another subclass (Grandparent â†’ Parent â†’ Child). âœ” Understanding how each subclass can access properties and methods of its parent and grandparent classes. âœ” Demonstrating method inheritance and overriding in a multilevel context (e.g., showGrandparent(), showParent(), showChild()). âœ” Understanding how Java resolves method calls through the chain of inheritance.Jain (Deemed-to-be University)Dr. Sanjeev Kumar Mandal, Ph.D, M.C.A, B.C.ADr Sagar Gulati

ğŸ’» Day 45: Method Overloading in SimpleMath ğŸ§¬ğŸ”„ What You Explored: âœ… The concept of method overloading, where you define multiple methods with the same name but different parameter types or number of parameters within the same class. âœ… How method overloading allows the same operation to be performed on different data types (e.g., int vs. double), providing flexibility and readability in the code. âœ… Real-world example of method overloading (e.g., a SimpleMath class with overloaded add(), sub(), and div() methods to handle both integer and floating-point numbers).ğŸ”¥ Why It Matters: Method overloading improves the versatility of your methods and makes your code more intuitive. Instead of creating multiple method names for similar operations, you can use the same method name with different parameters, keeping your code cleaner and easier to maintain. It helps you handle multiple scenarios with a single logical method name.ğŸ† What You Practiced: âœ” Creating overloaded methods with the same name but different parameter types (e.g., int vs. double). âœ” Understanding how Java resolves method calls based on the number and type of arguments passed. âœ” Demonstrating method overloading with arithmetic operations like addition, subtraction, and division. âœ” Calling overloaded methods with different argument types and observing the results.Jain (Deemed-to-be University) Dr. Sanjeev Kumar Mandal, Ph.D, M.C.A, B.C.A Dr Sagar Gulati

ğŸ’» Day 44: Multilevel Inheritance in Java (Grandparent â†’ Parent â†’ Child) ğŸ§¬ğŸ”„ What You Explored: âœ… The concept of multilevel inheritance, where a class (Child) inherits from another class (Parent), and that class (Parent) inherits from a third class (Grandparent). âœ… How multilevel inheritance creates a chain of class relationships, allowing subclasses to inherit behavior from multiple levels of the class hierarchy. âœ… Real-world example of multilevel inheritance (e.g., a Grandparent class, a Parent class, and a Child class, where the child inherits behavior from both the parent and the grandparent).ğŸ”¥ Why It Matters: Multilevel inheritance enables you to build more complex hierarchies of classes, allowing for a more structured and reusable design. It encourages the reuse of code at each level of the hierarchy while also enabling specialization and extension of functionality in subclasses. This makes the code more organized, easier to maintain, and scalable.ğŸ† What You Practiced: âœ” Creating a class hierarchy where a subclass inherits from another subclass (Grandparent â†’ Parent â†’ Child). âœ” Understanding how each subclass can access properties and methods of its parent and grandparent classes. âœ” Demonstrating method inheritance and overriding in a multilevel context (e.g., showGrandparent(), showParent(), showChild()). âœ” Understanding how Java resolves method calls through the chain of inheritance.Jain (Deemed-to-be University)Dr. Sanjeev Kumar Mandal, Ph.D, M.C.A, B.C.ADr Sagar Gulati

Instead of creating multiple method names for similar operations, you can use the same method name with different parameters, keeping your code cleaner and easier to maintain. It helps you handle multiple scenarios with a single logical method name.ğŸ† What You Practiced: âœ” Creating overloaded methods with the same name but different parameter types (e.g., int vs. double). âœ” Understanding how Java resolves method calls based on the number and type of arguments passed. âœ” Demonstrating method overloading with arithmetic operations like addition, subtraction, and division. âœ” Calling overloaded methods with different argument types and observing the results.Jain (Deemed-to-be University) Dr. Sanjeev Kumar Mandal, Ph.D, M.C.A, B.C.A Dr Sagar Gulati

ğŸ’» Day 44: Multilevel Inheritance in Java (Grandparent â†’ Parent â†’ Child) ğŸ§¬ğŸ”„ What You Explored: âœ… The concept of multilevel inheritance, where a class (Child) inherits from another class (Parent), and that class (Parent) inherits from a third class (Grandparent). âœ… How multilevel inheritance creates a chain of class relationships, allowing subclasses to inherit behavior from multiple levels of the class hierarchy. âœ… Real-world example of multilevel inheritance (e.g., a Grandparent class, a Parent class, and a Child class, where the child inherits behavior from both the parent and the grandparent).ğŸ”¥ Why It Matters: Multilevel inheritance enables you to build more complex hierarchies of classes, allowing for a more structured and reusable design. It encourages the reuse of code at each level of the hierarchy while also enabling specialization and extension of functionality in subclasses. This makes the code more organized, easier to maintain, and scalable.ğŸ† What You Practiced: âœ” Creating a class hierarchy where a subclass inherits from another subclass (Grandparent â†’ Parent â†’ Child). âœ” Understanding how each subclass can access properties and methods of its parent and grandparent classes. âœ” Demonstrating method inheritance and overriding in a multilevel context (e.g., showGrandparent(), showParent(), showChild()). âœ” Understanding how Java resolves method calls through the chain of inheritance.Jain (Deemed-to-be University)Dr. Sanjeev Kumar Mandal, Ph.D, M.C.A, B.C.ADr Sagar Gulati

ğŸ’» Day 43: Single Inheritance in Java ğŸ§¬ğŸ”„ What You Explored: âœ… The concept of single inheritance, where a subclass inherits properties and methods from a single superclass. âœ… How single inheritance allows you to create a hierarchy of classes, enabling code reuse and modularity. âœ… Real-world example of single inheritance (e.g., an Animal superclass and a Dog subclass where the dog inherits common behaviors from the animal).ğŸ”¥ Why It Matters: Single inheritance makes code more manageable by promoting reuse. By inheriting common features from a parent class, subclasses donâ€™t need to repeat code, which simplifies maintenance and makes your code more organized. It also allows for extending the behavior of a class without modifying the original code, promoting scalability.ğŸ† What You Practiced: âœ” Creating a superclass with common properties and methods. âœ” Implementing a subclass that inherits and extends the functionality of the superclass. âœ” Overriding methods in the subclass to customize behavior (e.g., animalâ€™s generic behavior vs. dogâ€™s specific behavior). âœ” Understanding the inheritance flow and how a subclass inherits fields and methods from its superclass.Let me know if you'd like a detailed example or if you have any questions!Jain (Deemed-to-be University) Dr. Sanjeev Kumar Mandal, Ph.D, M.C.A, B.C.ADr Sagar Gulati

ğŸ’» Day 45: Method Overloading in SimpleMath ğŸ§¬ğŸ”„ What You Explored: âœ… The concept of method overloading, where you define multiple methods with the same name but different parameter types or number of parameters within the same class. âœ… How method overloading allows the same operation to be performed on different data types (e.g., int vs. double), providing flexibility and readability in the code. âœ… Real-world example of method overloading (e.g., a SimpleMath class with overloaded add(), sub(), and div() methods to handle both integer and floating-point numbers).ğŸ”¥ Why It Matters: Method overloading improves the versatility of your methods and makes your code more intuitive. Instead of creating multiple method names for similar operations, you can use the same method name with different parameters, keeping your code cleaner and easier to maintain. It helps you handle multiple scenarios with a single logical method name.ğŸ† What You Practiced: âœ” Creating overloaded methods with the same name but different parameter types (e.g., int vs. double). âœ” Understanding how Java resolves method calls based on the number and type of arguments passed. âœ” Demonstrating method overloading with arithmetic operations like addition, subtraction, and division. âœ” Calling overloaded methods with different argument types and observing the results.Jain (Deemed-to-be University) Dr. Sanjeev Kumar Mandal, Ph.D, M.C.A, B.C.A Dr Sagar Gulati

ğŸ’» Day 44: Multilevel Inheritance in Java (Grandparent â†’ Parent â†’ Child) ğŸ§¬ğŸ”„ What You Explored: âœ… The concept of multilevel inheritance, where a class (Child) inherits from another class (Parent), and that class (Parent) inherits from a third class (Grandparent). âœ… How multilevel inheritance creates a chain of class relationships, allowing subclasses to inherit behavior from multiple levels of the class hierarchy. âœ… Real-world example of multilevel inheritance (e.g., a Grandparent class, a Parent class, and a Child class, where the child inherits behavior from both the parent and the grandparent).ğŸ”¥ Why It Matters: Multilevel inheritance enables you to build more complex hierarchies of classes, allowing for a more structured and reusable design. It encourages the reuse of code at each level of the hierarchy while also enabling specialization and extension of functionality in subclasses. This makes the code more organized, easier to maintain, and scalable.ğŸ† What You Practiced: âœ” Creating a class hierarchy where a subclass inherits from another subclass (Grandparent â†’ Parent â†’ Child). âœ” Understanding how each subclass can access properties and methods of its parent and grandparent classes. âœ” Demonstrating method inheritance and overriding in a multilevel context (e.g., showGrandparent(), showParent(), showChild()). âœ” Understanding how Java resolves method calls through the chain of inheritance.Jain (Deemed-to-be University)Dr. Sanjeev Kumar Mandal, Ph.D, M.C.A, B.C.ADr Sagar Gulati

ğŸ’» Day 43: Single Inheritance in Java ğŸ§¬ğŸ”„ What You Explored: âœ… The concept of single inheritance, where a subclass inherits properties and methods from a single superclass. âœ… How single inheritance allows you to create a hierarchy of classes, enabling code reuse and modularity. âœ… Real-world example of single inheritance (e.g., an Animal superclass and a Dog subclass where the dog inherits common behaviors from the animal).ğŸ”¥ Why It Matters: Single inheritance makes code more manageable by promoting reuse. By inheriting common features from a parent class, subclasses donâ€™t need to repeat code, which simplifies maintenance and makes your code more organized. It also allows for extending the behavior of a class without modifying the original code, promoting scalability.ğŸ† What You Practiced: âœ” Creating a superclass with common properties and methods. âœ” Implementing a subclass that inherits and extends the functionality of the superclass. âœ” Overriding methods in the subclass to customize behavior (e.g., animalâ€™s generic behavior vs. dogâ€™s specific behavior). âœ” Understanding the inheritance flow and how a subclass inherits fields and methods from its superclass.Let me know if you'd like a detailed example or if you have any questions!Jain (Deemed-to-be University) Dr. Sanjeev Kumar Mandal, Ph.D, M.C.A, B.C.ADr Sagar Gulati

ğŸ’» Day 45: Method Overloading in SimpleMath ğŸ§¬ğŸ”„ What You Explored: âœ… The concept of method overloading, where you define multiple methods with the same name but different parameter types or number of parameters within the same class. âœ… How method overloading allows the same operation to be performed on different data types (e.g., int vs. double), providing flexibility and readability in the code. âœ… Real-world example of method overloading (e.g., a SimpleMath class with overloaded add(), sub(), and div() methods to handle both integer and floating-point numbers).ğŸ”¥ Why It Matters: Method overloading improves the versatility of your methods and makes your code more intuitive. Instead of creating multiple method names for similar operations, you can use the same method name with different parameters, keeping your code cleaner and easier to maintain. It helps you handle multiple scenarios with a single logical method name.ğŸ† What You Practiced: âœ” Creating overloaded methods with the same name but different parameter types (e.g., int vs. double). âœ” Understanding how Java resolves method calls based on the number and type of arguments passed. âœ” Demonstrating method overloading with arithmetic operations like addition, subtraction, and division. âœ” Calling overloaded methods with different argument types and observing the results.Jain (Deemed-to-be University) Dr. Sanjeev Kumar Mandal, Ph.D, M.C.A, B.C.A Dr Sagar Gulati

ğŸ’» Day 44: Multilevel Inheritance in Java (Grandparent â†’ Parent â†’ Child) ğŸ§¬ğŸ”„ What You Explored: âœ… The concept of multilevel inheritance, where a class (Child) inherits from another class (Parent), and that class (Parent) inherits from a third class (Grandparent). âœ… How multilevel inheritance creates a chain of class relationships, allowing subclasses to inherit behavior from multiple levels of the class hierarchy. âœ… Real-world example of multilevel inheritance (e.g., a Grandparent class, a Parent class, and a Child class, where the child inherits behavior from both the parent and the grandparent).ğŸ”¥ Why It Matters: Multilevel inheritance enables you to build more complex hierarchies of classes, allowing for a more structured and reusable design. It encourages the reuse of code at each level of the hierarchy while also enabling specialization and extension of functionality in subclasses. This makes the code more organized, easier to maintain, and scalable.ğŸ† What You Practiced: âœ” Creating a class hierarchy where a subclass inherits from another subclass (Grandparent â†’ Parent â†’ Child). âœ” Understanding how each subclass can access properties and methods of its parent and grandparent classes. âœ” Demonstrating method inheritance and overriding in a multilevel context (e.g., showGrandparent(), showParent(), showChild()). âœ” Understanding how Java resolves method calls through the chain of inheritance.Jain (Deemed-to-be University)Dr. Sanjeev Kumar Mandal, Ph.D, M.C.A, B.C.ADr Sagar Gulati

ğŸ’» Day 46: Throw Example in Java ğŸ§¬ğŸ”„ What You Explored: âœ… The concept of using the throw keyword to explicitly throw exceptions in Java. âœ… How to create custom error messages when throwing exceptions to handle specific conditions in your code. âœ… A real-world example of throwing an exception when an invalid input is provided, such as when checking a person's age and ensuring it meets a certain criteria (e.g., age should be 18 or older).ğŸ”¥ Why It Matters: Using the throw keyword helps enforce rules and conditions in your code. It adds a layer of control and error management to your program, making it more robust and predictable.ğŸ† What You Practiced: âœ” Explicitly throwing exceptions using the throw keyword in response to invalid conditions. âœ” Creating custom exception messages to provide more meaningful feedback when an error occurs. âœ” Demonstrating how throwing an exception can stop the normal flow of execution and how you can handle errors by throwing exceptions deliberately. âœ” Understanding the role of exceptions in ensuring your program adheres to specific rules and logic (e.g., age validation).Jain (Deemed-to-be University)Dr. Sanjeev Kumar Mandal, Ph.D, M.C.A, B.C.ADr Sagar Gulati

ğŸ’» Day 45: Method Overloading in SimpleMath ğŸ§¬ğŸ”„ What You Explored: âœ… The concept of method overloading, where you define multiple methods with the same name but different parameter types or number of parameters within the same class. âœ… How method overloading allows the same operation to be performed on different data types (e.g., int vs. double), providing flexibility and readability in the code. âœ… Real-world example of method overloading (e.g., a SimpleMath class with overloaded add(), sub(), and div() methods to handle both integer and floating-point numbers).ğŸ”¥ Why It Matters: Method overloading improves the versatility of your methods and makes your code more intuitive. Instead of creating multiple method names for similar operations, you can use the same method name with different parameters, keeping your code cleaner and easier to maintain. It helps you handle multiple scenarios with a single logical method name.ğŸ† What You Practiced: âœ” Creating overloaded methods with the same name but different parameter types (e.g., int vs. double). âœ” Understanding how Java resolves method calls based on the number and type of arguments passed. âœ” Demonstrating method overloading with arithmetic operations like addition, subtraction, and division. âœ” Calling overloaded methods with different argument types and observing the results.Jain (Deemed-to-be University) Dr. Sanjeev Kumar Mandal, Ph.D, M.C.A, B.C.A Dr Sagar Gulati

ğŸ’» Day 44: Multilevel Inheritance in Java (Grandparent â†’ Parent â†’ Child) ğŸ§¬ğŸ”„ What You Explored: âœ… The concept of multilevel inheritance, where a class (Child) inherits from another class (Parent), and that class (Parent) inherits from a third class (Grandparent). âœ… How multilevel inheritance creates a chain of class relationships, allowing subclasses to inherit behavior from multiple levels of the class hierarchy. âœ… Real-world example of multilevel inheritance (e.g., a Grandparent class, a Parent class, and a Child class, where the child inherits behavior from both the parent and the grandparent).ğŸ”¥ Why It Matters: Multilevel inheritance enables you to build more complex hierarchies of classes, allowing for a more structured and reusable design. It encourages the reuse of code at each level of the hierarchy while also enabling specialization and extension of functionality in subclasses. This makes the code more organized, easier to maintain, and scalable.ğŸ† What You Practiced: âœ” Creating a class hierarchy where a subclass inherits from another subclass (Grandparent â†’ Parent â†’ Child). âœ” Understanding how each subclass can access properties and methods of its parent and grandparent classes. âœ” Demonstrating method inheritance and overriding in a multilevel context (e.g., showGrandparent(), showParent(), showChild()). âœ” Understanding how Java resolves method calls through the chain of inheritance.Jain (Deemed-to-be University)Dr. Sanjeev Kumar Mandal, Ph.D, M.C.A, B.C.ADr Sagar Gulati

By inheriting common features from a parent class, subclasses donâ€™t need to repeat code, which simplifies maintenance and makes your code more organized. It also allows for extending the behavior of a class without modifying the original code, promoting scalability.ğŸ† What You Practiced: âœ” Creating a superclass with common properties and methods. âœ” Implementing a subclass that inherits and extends the functionality of the superclass. âœ” Overriding methods in the subclass to customize behavior (e.g., animalâ€™s generic behavior vs. dogâ€™s specific behavior). âœ” Understanding the inheritance flow and how a subclass inherits fields and methods from its superclass.Let me know if you'd like a detailed example or if you have any questions!Jain (Deemed-to-be University) Dr. Sanjeev Kumar Mandal, Ph.D, M.C.A, B.C.ADr Sagar Gulati

ğŸ’» Day 45: Method Overloading in SimpleMath ğŸ§¬ğŸ”„ What You Explored: âœ… The concept of method overloading, where you define multiple methods with the same name but different parameter types or number of parameters within the same class. âœ… How method overloading allows the same operation to be performed on different data types (e.g., int vs. double), providing flexibility and readability in the code. âœ… Real-world example of method overloading (e.g., a SimpleMath class with overloaded add(), sub(), and div() methods to handle both integer and floating-point numbers).ğŸ”¥ Why It Matters: Method overloading improves the versatility of your methods and makes your code more intuitive. Instead of creating multiple method names for similar operations, you can use the same method name with different parameters, keeping your code cleaner and easier to maintain. It helps you handle multiple scenarios with a single logical method name.ğŸ† What You Practiced: âœ” Creating overloaded methods with the same name but different parameter types (e.g., int vs. double). âœ” Understanding how Java resolves method calls based on the number and type of arguments passed. âœ” Demonstrating method overloading with arithmetic operations like addition, subtraction, and division. âœ” Calling overloaded methods with different argument types and observing the results.Jain (Deemed-to-be University) Dr. Sanjeev Kumar Mandal, Ph.D, M.C.A, B.C.A Dr Sagar Gulati

ğŸ’» Day 44: Multilevel Inheritance in Java (Grandparent â†’ Parent â†’ Child) ğŸ§¬ğŸ”„ What You Explored: âœ… The concept of multilevel inheritance, where a class (Child) inherits from another class (Parent), and that class (Parent) inherits from a third class (Grandparent). âœ… How multilevel inheritance creates a chain of class relationships, allowing subclasses to inherit behavior from multiple levels of the class hierarchy. âœ… Real-world example of multilevel inheritance (e.g., a Grandparent class, a Parent class, and a Child class, where the child inherits behavior from both the parent and the grandparent).ğŸ”¥ Why It Matters: Multilevel inheritance enables you to build more complex hierarchies of classes, allowing for a more structured and reusable design. It encourages the reuse of code at each level of the hierarchy while also enabling specialization and extension of functionality in subclasses. This makes the code more organized, easier to maintain, and scalable.ğŸ† What You Practiced: âœ” Creating a class hierarchy where a subclass inherits from another subclass (Grandparent â†’ Parent â†’ Child). âœ” Understanding how each subclass can access properties and methods of its parent and grandparent classes. âœ” Demonstrating method inheritance and overriding in a multilevel context (e.g., showGrandparent(), showParent(), showChild()). âœ” Understanding how Java resolves method calls through the chain of inheritance.Jain (Deemed-to-be University)Dr. Sanjeev Kumar Mandal, Ph.D, M.C.A, B.C.ADr Sagar Gulati

ğŸ’» Day 45: Method Overloading in SimpleMath ğŸ§¬ğŸ”„ What You Explored: âœ… The concept of method overloading, where you define multiple methods with the same name but different parameter types or number of parameters within the same class. âœ… How method overloading allows the same operation to be performed on different data types (e.g., int vs. double), providing flexibility and readability in the code. âœ… Real-world example of method overloading (e.g., a SimpleMath class with overloaded add(), sub(), and div() methods to handle both integer and floating-point numbers).ğŸ”¥ Why It Matters: Method overloading improves the versatility of your methods and makes your code more intuitive. Instead of creating multiple method names for similar operations, you can use the same method name with different parameters, keeping your code cleaner and easier to maintain. It helps you handle multiple scenarios with a single logical method name.ğŸ† What You Practiced: âœ” Creating overloaded methods with the same name but different parameter types (e.g., int vs. double). âœ” Understanding how Java resolves method calls based on the number and type of arguments passed. âœ” Demonstrating method overloading with arithmetic operations like addition, subtraction, and division. âœ” Calling overloaded methods with different argument types and observing the results.Jain (Deemed-to-be University) Dr. Sanjeev Kumar Mandal, Ph.D, M.C.A, B.C.A Dr Sagar Gulati

ğŸ’» Day 44: Multilevel Inheritance in Java (Grandparent â†’ Parent â†’ Child) ğŸ§¬ğŸ”„ What You Explored: âœ… The concept of multilevel inheritance, where a class (Child) inherits from another class (Parent), and that class (Parent) inherits from a third class (Grandparent). âœ… How multilevel inheritance creates a chain of class relationships, allowing subclasses to inherit behavior from multiple levels of the class hierarchy. âœ… Real-world example of multilevel inheritance (e.g., a Grandparent class, a Parent class, and a Child class, where the child inherits behavior from both the parent and the grandparent).ğŸ”¥ Why It Matters: Multilevel inheritance enables you to build more complex hierarchies of classes, allowing for a more structured and reusable design. It encourages the reuse of code at each level of the hierarchy while also enabling specialization and extension of functionality in subclasses. This makes the code more organized, easier to maintain, and scalable.ğŸ† What You Practiced: âœ” Creating a class hierarchy where a subclass inherits from another subclass (Grandparent â†’ Parent â†’ Child). âœ” Understanding how each subclass can access properties and methods of its parent and grandparent classes. âœ” Demonstrating method inheritance and overriding in a multilevel context (e.g., showGrandparent(), showParent(), showChild()). âœ” Understanding how Java resolves method calls through the chain of inheritance.Jain (Deemed-to-be University)Dr. Sanjeev Kumar Mandal, Ph.D, M.C.A, B.C.ADr Sagar Gulati

By inheriting common features from a parent class, subclasses donâ€™t need to repeat code, which simplifies maintenance and makes your code more organized. It also allows for extending the behavior of a class without modifying the original code, promoting scalability.ğŸ† What You Practiced: âœ” Creating a superclass with common properties and methods. âœ” Implementing a subclass that inherits and extends the functionality of the superclass. âœ” Overriding methods in the subclass to customize behavior (e.g., animalâ€™s generic behavior vs. dogâ€™s specific behavior). âœ” Understanding the inheritance flow and how a subclass inherits fields and methods from its superclass.Let me know if you'd like a detailed example or if you have any questions!Jain (Deemed-to-be University) Dr. Sanjeev Kumar Mandal, Ph.D, M.C.A, B.C.ADr Sagar Gulati

ğŸ’» Day 45: Method Overloading in SimpleMath ğŸ§¬ğŸ”„ What You Explored: âœ… The concept of method overloading, where you define multiple methods with the same name but different parameter types or number of parameters within the same class. âœ… How method overloading allows the same operation to be performed on different data types (e.g., int vs. double), providing flexibility and readability in the code. âœ… Real-world example of method overloading (e.g., a SimpleMath class with overloaded add(), sub(), and div() methods to handle both integer and floating-point numbers).ğŸ”¥ Why It Matters: Method overloading improves the versatility of your methods and makes your code more intuitive. Instead of creating multiple method names for similar operations, you can use the same method name with different parameters, keeping your code cleaner and easier to maintain. It helps you handle multiple scenarios with a single logical method name.ğŸ† What You Practiced: âœ” Creating overloaded methods with the same name but different parameter types (e.g., int vs. double). âœ” Understanding how Java resolves method calls based on the number and type of arguments passed. âœ” Demonstrating method overloading with arithmetic operations like addition, subtraction, and division. âœ” Calling overloaded methods with different argument types and observing the results.Jain (Deemed-to-be University) Dr. Sanjeev Kumar Mandal, Ph.D, M.C.A, B.C.A Dr Sagar Gulati

ğŸ’» Day 44: Multilevel Inheritance in Java (Grandparent â†’ Parent â†’ Child) ğŸ§¬ğŸ”„ What You Explored: âœ… The concept of multilevel inheritance, where a class (Child) inherits from another class (Parent), and that class (Parent) inherits from a third class (Grandparent). âœ… How multilevel inheritance creates a chain of class relationships, allowing subclasses to inherit behavior from multiple levels of the class hierarchy. âœ… Real-world example of multilevel inheritance (e.g., a Grandparent class, a Parent class, and a Child class, where the child inherits behavior from both the parent and the grandparent).ğŸ”¥ Why It Matters: Multilevel inheritance enables you to build more complex hierarchies of classes, allowing for a more structured and reusable design. It encourages the reuse of code at each level of the hierarchy while also enabling specialization and extension of functionality in subclasses. This makes the code more organized, easier to maintain, and scalable.ğŸ† What You Practiced: âœ” Creating a class hierarchy where a subclass inherits from another subclass (Grandparent â†’ Parent â†’ Child). âœ” Understanding how each subclass can access properties and methods of its parent and grandparent classes. âœ” Demonstrating method inheritance and overriding in a multilevel context (e.g., showGrandparent(), showParent(), showChild()). âœ” Understanding how Java resolves method calls through the chain of inheritance.Jain (Deemed-to-be University)Dr. Sanjeev Kumar Mandal, Ph.D, M.C.A, B.C.ADr Sagar Gulati

By inheriting common features from a parent class, subclasses donâ€™t need to repeat code, which simplifies maintenance and makes your code more organized. It also allows for extending the behavior of a class without modifying the original code, promoting scalability.ğŸ† What You Practiced: âœ” Creating a superclass with common properties and methods. âœ” Implementing a subclass that inherits and extends the functionality of the superclass. âœ” Overriding methods in the subclass to customize behavior (e.g., animalâ€™s generic behavior vs. dogâ€™s specific behavior). âœ” Understanding the inheritance flow and how a subclass inherits fields and methods from its superclass.Let me know if you'd like a detailed example or if you have any questions!Jain (Deemed-to-be University) Dr. Sanjeev Kumar Mandal, Ph.D, M.C.A, B.C.ADr Sagar Gulati

ğŸ’» Day 45: Method Overloading in SimpleMath ğŸ§¬ğŸ”„ What You Explored: âœ… The concept of method overloading, where you define multiple methods with the same name but different parameter types or number of parameters within the same class. âœ… How method overloading allows the same operation to be performed on different data types (e.g., int vs. double), providing flexibility and readability in the code. âœ… Real-world example of method overloading (e.g., a SimpleMath class with overloaded add(), sub(), and div() methods to handle both integer and floating-point numbers).ğŸ”¥ Why It Matters: Method overloading improves the versatility of your methods and makes your code more intuitive. Instead of creating multiple method names for similar operations, you can use the same method name with different parameters, keeping your code cleaner and easier to maintain. It helps you handle multiple scenarios with a single logical method name.ğŸ† What You Practiced: âœ” Creating overloaded methods with the same name but different parameter types (e.g., int vs. double). âœ” Understanding how Java resolves method calls based on the number and type of arguments passed. âœ” Demonstrating method overloading with arithmetic operations like addition, subtraction, and division. âœ” Calling overloaded methods with different argument types and observing the results.Jain (Deemed-to-be University) Dr. Sanjeev Kumar Mandal, Ph.D, M.C.A, B.C.A Dr Sagar Gulati

ğŸ’» Day 44: Multilevel Inheritance in Java (Grandparent â†’ Parent â†’ Child) ğŸ§¬ğŸ”„ What You Explored: âœ… The concept of multilevel inheritance, where a class (Child) inherits from another class (Parent), and that class (Parent) inherits from a third class (Grandparent). âœ… How multilevel inheritance creates a chain of class relationships, allowing subclasses to inherit behavior from multiple levels of the class hierarchy. âœ… Real-world example of multilevel inheritance (e.g., a Grandparent class, a Parent class, and a Child class, where the child inherits behavior from both the parent and the grandparent).ğŸ”¥ Why It Matters: Multilevel inheritance enables you to build more complex hierarchies of classes, allowing for a more structured and reusable design. It encourages the reuse of code at each level of the hierarchy while also enabling specialization and extension of functionality in subclasses. This makes the code more organized, easier to maintain, and scalable.ğŸ† What You Practiced: âœ” Creating a class hierarchy where a subclass inherits from another subclass (Grandparent â†’ Parent â†’ Child). âœ” Understanding how each subclass can access properties and methods of its parent and grandparent classes. âœ” Demonstrating method inheritance and overriding in a multilevel context (e.g., showGrandparent(), showParent(), showChild()). âœ” Understanding how Java resolves method calls through the chain of inheritance.Jain (Deemed-to-be University)Dr. Sanjeev Kumar Mandal, Ph.D, M.C.A, B.C.ADr Sagar Gulati

ğŸ’» Day 45: Method Overloading in Simple Math ğŸ”„ What You Explored: âœ… The concept of method overloading, where you define multiple methods with the same name but different parameter types or number of parameters within the same class. âœ… How method overloading allows the same operation to be performed on different data types (e.g., int vs. double), providing flexibility and readability in the code. âœ… Real-world example of method overloading (e.g., a SimpleMath class with overloaded add(), sub(), and div() methods to handle both integer and floating-point numbers).ğŸ”¥ Why It Matters: Method overloading improves the versatility of your methods and makes your code more intuitive. Instead of creating multiple method names for similar operations, you can use the same method name with different parameters, keeping your code cleaner and easier to maintain. It helps you handle multiple scenarios with a single logical method name.ğŸ† What You Practiced: âœ” Creating overloaded methods with the same name but different parameter types (e.g., int vs. double). âœ” Understanding how Java resolves method calls based on the number and type of arguments passed. âœ” Demonstrating method overloading with arithmetic operations like addition, subtraction, and division. âœ” Calling overloaded methods with different argument types and observing the results.Jain (Deemed-to-be University)Dr. Sanjeev Kumar Mandal, Ph.D, M.C.A, B.C.A,Dr Sagar Gulati

ğŸ’» Day 45: Method Overloading in SimpleMath ğŸ§¬ğŸ”„ What You Explored: âœ… The concept of method overloading, where you define multiple methods with the same name but different parameter types or number of parameters within the same class. âœ… How method overloading allows the same operation to be performed on different data types (e.g., int vs. double), providing flexibility and readability in the code. âœ… Real-world example of method overloading (e.g., a SimpleMath class with overloaded add(), sub(), and div() methods to handle both integer and floating-point numbers).ğŸ”¥ Why It Matters: Method overloading improves the versatility of your methods and makes your code more intuitive. Instead of creating multiple method names for similar operations, you can use the same method name with different parameters, keeping your code cleaner and easier to maintain. It helps you handle multiple scenarios with a single logical method name.ğŸ† What You Practiced: âœ” Creating overloaded methods with the same name but different parameter types (e.g., int vs. double). âœ” Understanding how Java resolves method calls based on the number and type of arguments passed. âœ” Demonstrating method overloading with arithmetic operations like addition, subtraction, and division. âœ” Calling overloaded methods with different argument types and observing the results.Jain (Deemed-to-be University) Dr. Sanjeev Kumar Mandal, Ph.D, M.C.A, B.C.A Dr Sagar Gulati

ğŸ’» Day 44: Multilevel Inheritance in Java (Grandparent â†’ Parent â†’ Child) ğŸ§¬ğŸ”„ What You Explored: âœ… The concept of multilevel inheritance, where a class (Child) inherits from another class (Parent), and that class (Parent) inherits from a third class (Grandparent). âœ… How multilevel inheritance creates a chain of class relationships, allowing subclasses to inherit behavior from multiple levels of the class hierarchy. âœ… Real-world example of multilevel inheritance (e.g., a Grandparent class, a Parent class, and a Child class, where the child inherits behavior from both the parent and the grandparent).ğŸ”¥ Why It Matters: Multilevel inheritance enables you to build more complex hierarchies of classes, allowing for a more structured and reusable design. It encourages the reuse of code at each level of the hierarchy while also enabling specialization and extension of functionality in subclasses. This makes the code more organized, easier to maintain, and scalable.ğŸ† What You Practiced: âœ” Creating a class hierarchy where a subclass inherits from another subclass (Grandparent â†’ Parent â†’ Child). âœ” Understanding how each subclass can access properties and methods of its parent and grandparent classes. âœ” Demonstrating method inheritance and overriding in a multilevel context (e.g., showGrandparent(), showParent(), showChild()). âœ” Understanding how Java resolves method calls through the chain of inheritance.Jain (Deemed-to-be University)Dr. Sanjeev Kumar Mandal, Ph.D, M.C.A, B.C.ADr Sagar Gulati

It also allows for extending the behavior of a class without modifying the original code, promoting scalability.ğŸ† What You Practiced: âœ” Creating a superclass with common properties and methods. âœ” Implementing a subclass that inherits and extends the functionality of the superclass. âœ” Overriding methods in the subclass to customize behavior (e.g., animalâ€™s generic behavior vs. dogâ€™s specific behavior). âœ” Understanding the inheritance flow and how a subclass inherits fields and methods from its superclass.Let me know if you'd like a detailed example or if you have any questions!Jain (Deemed-to-be University) Dr. Sanjeev Kumar Mandal, Ph.D, M.C.A, B.C.ADr Sagar Gulati

ğŸ’» Day 46: Throw Example in Java ğŸ§¬ğŸ”„ What You Explored: âœ… The concept of using the throw keyword to explicitly throw exceptions in Java. âœ… How to create custom error messages when throwing exceptions to handle specific conditions in your code. âœ… A real-world example of throwing an exception when an invalid input is provided, such as when checking a person's age and ensuring it meets a certain criteria (e.g., age should be 18 or older).ğŸ”¥ Why It Matters: Using the throw keyword helps enforce rules and conditions in your code. It adds a layer of control and error management to your program, making it more robust and predictable.ğŸ† What You Practiced: âœ” Explicitly throwing exceptions using the throw keyword in response to invalid conditions. âœ” Creating custom exception messages to provide more meaningful feedback when an error occurs. âœ” Demonstrating how throwing an exception can stop the normal flow of execution and how you can handle errors by throwing exceptions deliberately. âœ” Understanding the role of exceptions in ensuring your program adheres to specific rules and logic (e.g., age validation).Jain (Deemed-to-be University)Dr. Sanjeev Kumar Mandal, Ph.D, M.C.A, B.C.ADr Sagar Gulati

ğŸ’» Day 45: Method Overloading in SimpleMath ğŸ§¬ğŸ”„ What You Explored: âœ… The concept of method overloading, where you define multiple methods with the same name but different parameter types or number of parameters within the same class. âœ… How method overloading allows the same operation to be performed on different data types (e.g., int vs. double), providing flexibility and readability in the code. âœ… Real-world example of method overloading (e.g., a SimpleMath class with overloaded add(), sub(), and div() methods to handle both integer and floating-point numbers).ğŸ”¥ Why It Matters: Method overloading improves the versatility of your methods and makes your code more intuitive. Instead of creating multiple method names for similar operations, you can use the same method name with different parameters, keeping your code cleaner and easier to maintain. It helps you handle multiple scenarios with a single logical method name.ğŸ† What You Practiced: âœ” Creating overloaded methods with the same name but different parameter types (e.g., int vs. double). âœ” Understanding how Java resolves method calls based on the number and type of arguments passed. âœ” Demonstrating method overloading with arithmetic operations like addition, subtraction, and division. âœ” Calling overloaded methods with different argument types and observing the results.Jain (Deemed-to-be University) Dr. Sanjeev Kumar Mandal, Ph.D, M.C.A, B.C.A Dr Sagar Gulati

ğŸ’» Day 44: Multilevel Inheritance in Java (Grandparent â†’ Parent â†’ Child) ğŸ§¬ğŸ”„ What You Explored: âœ… The concept of multilevel inheritance, where a class (Child) inherits from another class (Parent), and that class (Parent) inherits from a third class (Grandparent). âœ… How multilevel inheritance creates a chain of class relationships, allowing subclasses to inherit behavior from multiple levels of the class hierarchy. âœ… Real-world example of multilevel inheritance (e.g., a Grandparent class, a Parent class, and a Child class, where the child inherits behavior from both the parent and the grandparent).ğŸ”¥ Why It Matters: Multilevel inheritance enables you to build more complex hierarchies of classes, allowing for a more structured and reusable design. It encourages the reuse of code at each level of the hierarchy while also enabling specialization and extension of functionality in subclasses. This makes the code more organized, easier to maintain, and scalable.ğŸ† What You Practiced: âœ” Creating a class hierarchy where a subclass inherits from another subclass (Grandparent â†’ Parent â†’ Child). âœ” Understanding how each subclass can access properties and methods of its parent and grandparent classes. âœ” Demonstrating method inheritance and overriding in a multilevel context (e.g., showGrandparent(), showParent(), showChild()). âœ” Understanding how Java resolves method calls through the chain of inheritance.Jain (Deemed-to-be University)Dr. Sanjeev Kumar Mandal, Ph.D, M.C.A, B.C.ADr Sagar Gulati

ğŸ’» Day 45: Method Overloading in SimpleMath ğŸ§¬ğŸ”„ What You Explored: âœ… The concept of method overloading, where you define multiple methods with the same name but different parameter types or number of parameters within the same class. âœ… How method overloading allows the same operation to be performed on different data types (e.g., int vs. double), providing flexibility and readability in the code. âœ… Real-world example of method overloading (e.g., a SimpleMath class with overloaded add(), sub(), and div() methods to handle both integer and floating-point numbers).ğŸ”¥ Why It Matters: Method overloading improves the versatility of your methods and makes your code more intuitive. Instead of creating multiple method names for similar operations, you can use the same method name with different parameters, keeping your code cleaner and easier to maintain. It helps you handle multiple scenarios with a single logical method name.ğŸ† What You Practiced: âœ” Creating overloaded methods with the same name but different parameter types (e.g., int vs. double). âœ” Understanding how Java resolves method calls based on the number and type of arguments passed. âœ” Demonstrating method overloading with arithmetic operations like addition, subtraction, and division. âœ” Calling overloaded methods with different argument types and observing the results.Jain (Deemed-to-be University) Dr. Sanjeev Kumar Mandal, Ph.D, M.C.A, B.C.A Dr Sagar Gulati

ğŸ’» Day 44: Multilevel Inheritance in Java (Grandparent â†’ Parent â†’ Child) ğŸ§¬ğŸ”„ What You Explored: âœ… The concept of multilevel inheritance, where a class (Child) inherits from another class (Parent), and that class (Parent) inherits from a third class (Grandparent). âœ… How multilevel inheritance creates a chain of class relationships, allowing subclasses to inherit behavior from multiple levels of the class hierarchy. âœ… Real-world example of multilevel inheritance (e.g., a Grandparent class, a Parent class, and a Child class, where the child inherits behavior from both the parent and the grandparent).ğŸ”¥ Why It Matters: Multilevel inheritance enables you to build more complex hierarchies of classes, allowing for a more structured and reusable design. It encourages the reuse of code at each level of the hierarchy while also enabling specialization and extension of functionality in subclasses. This makes the code more organized, easier to maintain, and scalable.ğŸ† What You Practiced: âœ” Creating a class hierarchy where a subclass inherits from another subclass (Grandparent â†’ Parent â†’ Child). âœ” Understanding how each subclass can access properties and methods of its parent and grandparent classes. âœ” Demonstrating method inheritance and overriding in a multilevel context (e.g., showGrandparent(), showParent(), showChild()). âœ” Understanding how Java resolves method calls through the chain of inheritance.Jain (Deemed-to-be University)Dr. Sanjeev Kumar Mandal, Ph.D, M.C.A, B.C.ADr Sagar Gulati

ğŸ’» Day 45: Method Overloading in SimpleMath ğŸ§¬ğŸ”„ What You Explored: âœ… The concept of method overloading, where you define multiple methods with the same name but different parameter types or number of parameters within the same class. âœ… How method overloading allows the same operation to be performed on different data types (e.g., int vs. double), providing flexibility and readability in the code. âœ… Real-world example of method overloading (e.g., a SimpleMath class with overloaded add(), sub(), and div() methods to handle both integer and floating-point numbers).ğŸ”¥ Why It Matters: Method overloading improves the versatility of your methods and makes your code more intuitive. Instead of creating multiple method names for similar operations, you can use the same method name with different parameters, keeping your code cleaner and easier to maintain. It helps you handle multiple scenarios with a single logical method name.ğŸ† What You Practiced: âœ” Creating overloaded methods with the same name but different parameter types (e.g., int vs. double). âœ” Understanding how Java resolves method calls based on the number and type of arguments passed. âœ” Demonstrating method overloading with arithmetic operations like addition, subtraction, and division. âœ” Calling overloaded methods with different argument types and observing the results.Jain (Deemed-to-be University) Dr. Sanjeev Kumar Mandal, Ph.D, M.C.A, B.C.A Dr Sagar Gulati

ğŸ’» Day 44: Multilevel Inheritance in Java (Grandparent â†’ Parent â†’ Child) ğŸ§¬ğŸ”„ What You Explored: âœ… The concept of multilevel inheritance, where a class (Child) inherits from another class (Parent), and that class (Parent) inherits from a third class (Grandparent). âœ… How multilevel inheritance creates a chain of class relationships, allowing subclasses to inherit behavior from multiple levels of the class hierarchy. âœ… Real-world example of multilevel inheritance (e.g., a Grandparent class, a Parent class, and a Child class, where the child inherits behavior from both the parent and the grandparent).ğŸ”¥ Why It Matters: Multilevel inheritance enables you to build more complex hierarchies of classes, allowing for a more structured and reusable design. It encourages the reuse of code at each level of the hierarchy while also enabling specialization and extension of functionality in subclasses. This makes the code more organized, easier to maintain, and scalable.ğŸ† What You Practiced: âœ” Creating a class hierarchy where a subclass inherits from another subclass (Grandparent â†’ Parent â†’ Child). âœ” Understanding how each subclass can access properties and methods of its parent and grandparent classes. âœ” Demonstrating method inheritance and overriding in a multilevel context (e.g., showGrandparent(), showParent(), showChild()). âœ” Understanding how Java resolves method calls through the chain of inheritance.Jain (Deemed-to-be University)Dr. Sanjeev Kumar Mandal, Ph.D, M.C.A, B.C.ADr Sagar Gulati

ğŸ’» Day 45: Method Overloading in Simple Math ğŸ”„ What You Explored: âœ… The concept of method overloading, where you define multiple methods with the same name but different parameter types or number of parameters within the same class. âœ… How method overloading allows the same operation to be performed on different data types (e.g., int vs. double), providing flexibility and readability in the code. âœ… Real-world example of method overloading (e.g., a SimpleMath class with overloaded add(), sub(), and div() methods to handle both integer and floating-point numbers).ğŸ”¥ Why It Matters: Method overloading improves the versatility of your methods and makes your code more intuitive. Instead of creating multiple method names for similar operations, you can use the same method name with different parameters, keeping your code cleaner and easier to maintain. It helps you handle multiple scenarios with a single logical method name.ğŸ† What You Practiced: âœ” Creating overloaded methods with the same name but different parameter types (e.g., int vs. double). âœ” Understanding how Java resolves method calls based on the number and type of arguments passed. âœ” Demonstrating method overloading with arithmetic operations like addition, subtraction, and division. âœ” Calling overloaded methods with different argument types and observing the results.Jain (Deemed-to-be University)Dr. Sanjeev Kumar Mandal, Ph.D, M.C.A, B.C.A,Dr Sagar Gulati

ğŸ’» Day 44: Multilevel Inheritance in Java (Grandparent â†’ Parent â†’ Child) ğŸ§¬ğŸ”„ What You Explored: âœ… The concept of multilevel inheritance, where a class (Child) inherits from another class (Parent), and that class (Parent) inherits from a third class (Grandparent). âœ… How multilevel inheritance creates a chain of class relationships, allowing subclasses to inherit behavior from multiple levels of the class hierarchy. âœ… Real-world example of multilevel inheritance (e.g., a Grandparent class, a Parent class, and a Child class, where the child inherits behavior from both the parent and the grandparent).ğŸ”¥ Why It Matters: Multilevel inheritance enables you to build more complex hierarchies of classes, allowing for a more structured and reusable design. This makes the code more organized, easier to maintain, and scalable.ğŸ† What You Practiced: âœ” Creating a class hierarchy where a subclass inherits from another subclass (Grandparent â†’ Parent â†’ Child). âœ” Understanding how each subclass can access properties and methods of its parent and grandparent classes. âœ” Demonstrating method inheritance and overriding in a multilevel context (e.g., showGrandparent(), showParent(), showChild()). âœ” Understanding how Java resolves method calls through the chain of inheritance.Jain (Deemed-to-be University)Dr. Sanjeev Kumar Mandal, Ph.D, M.C.A, B.C.ADr Sagar Gulati

ğŸ’» Day 45: Method Overloading in Simple Math ğŸ”„ What You Explored: âœ… The concept of method overloading, where you define multiple methods with the same name but different parameter types or number of parameters within the same class. âœ… How method overloading allows the same operation to be performed on different data types (e.g., int vs. double), providing flexibility and readability in the code. âœ… Real-world example of method overloading (e.g., a SimpleMath class with overloaded add(), sub(), and div() methods to handle both integer and floating-point numbers).ğŸ”¥ Why It Matters: Method overloading improves the versatility of your methods and makes your code more intuitive. Instead of creating multiple method names for similar operations, you can use the same method name with different parameters, keeping your code cleaner and easier to maintain. It helps you handle multiple scenarios with a single logical method name.ğŸ† What You Practiced: âœ” Creating overloaded methods with the same name but different parameter types (e.g., int vs. double). âœ” Understanding how Java resolves method calls based on the number and type of arguments passed. âœ” Demonstrating method overloading with arithmetic operations like addition, subtraction, and division. âœ” Calling overloaded methods with different argument types and observing the results.Jain (Deemed-to-be University)Dr. Sanjeev Kumar Mandal, Ph.D, M.C.A, B.C.A,Dr Sagar Gulati

ğŸ’» Day 45: Method Overloading in SimpleMath ğŸ§¬ğŸ”„ What You Explored: âœ… The concept of method overloading, where you define multiple methods with the same name but different parameter types or number of parameters within the same class. âœ… How method overloading allows the same operation to be performed on different data types (e.g., int vs. double), providing flexibility and readability in the code. âœ… Real-world example of method overloading (e.g., a SimpleMath class with overloaded add(), sub(), and div() methods to handle both integer and floating-point numbers).ğŸ”¥ Why It Matters: Method overloading improves the versatility of your methods and makes your code more intuitive. Instead of creating multiple method names for similar operations, you can use the same method name with different parameters, keeping your code cleaner and easier to maintain. It helps you handle multiple scenarios with a single logical method name.ğŸ† What You Practiced: âœ” Creating overloaded methods with the same name but different parameter types (e.g., int vs. double). âœ” Understanding how Java resolves method calls based on the number and type of arguments passed. âœ” Demonstrating method overloading with arithmetic operations like addition, subtraction, and division. âœ” Calling overloaded methods with different argument types and observing the results.Jain (Deemed-to-be University) Dr. Sanjeev Kumar Mandal, Ph.D, M.C.A, B.C.A Dr Sagar Gulati

ğŸ’» Day 44: Multilevel Inheritance in Java (Grandparent â†’ Parent â†’ Child) ğŸ§¬ğŸ”„ What You Explored: âœ… The concept of multilevel inheritance, where a class (Child) inherits from another class (Parent), and that class (Parent) inherits from a third class (Grandparent). âœ… How multilevel inheritance creates a chain of class relationships, allowing subclasses to inherit behavior from multiple levels of the class hierarchy. âœ… Real-world example of multilevel inheritance (e.g., a Grandparent class, a Parent class, and a Child class, where the child inherits behavior from both the parent and the grandparent).ğŸ”¥ Why It Matters: Multilevel inheritance enables you to build more complex hierarchies of classes, allowing for a more structured and reusable design. It encourages the reuse of code at each level of the hierarchy while also enabling specialization and extension of functionality in subclasses. This makes the code more organized, easier to maintain, and scalable.ğŸ† What You Practiced: âœ” Creating a class hierarchy where a subclass inherits from another subclass (Grandparent â†’ Parent â†’ Child). âœ” Understanding how each subclass can access properties and methods of its parent and grandparent classes. âœ” Demonstrating method inheritance and overriding in a multilevel context (e.g., showGrandparent(), showParent(), showChild()). âœ” Understanding how Java resolves method calls through the chain of inheritance.Jain (Deemed-to-be University)Dr. Sanjeev Kumar Mandal, Ph.D, M.C.A, B.C.ADr Sagar Gulati

ğŸ’» Day 45: Method Overloading in SimpleMath ğŸ§¬ğŸ”„ What You Explored: âœ… The concept of method overloading, where you define multiple methods with the same name but different parameter types or number of parameters within the same class. âœ… How method overloading allows the same operation to be performed on different data types (e.g., int vs. double), providing flexibility and readability in the code. âœ… Real-world example of method overloading (e.g., a SimpleMath class with overloaded add(), sub(), and div() methods to handle both integer and floating-point numbers).ğŸ”¥ Why It Matters: Method overloading improves the versatility of your methods and makes your code more intuitive. Instead of creating multiple method names for similar operations, you can use the same method name with different parameters, keeping your code cleaner and easier to maintain. It helps you handle multiple scenarios with a single logical method name.ğŸ† What You Practiced: âœ” Creating overloaded methods with the same name but different parameter types (e.g., int vs. double). âœ” Understanding how Java resolves method calls based on the number and type of arguments passed. âœ” Demonstrating method overloading with arithmetic operations like addition, subtraction, and division. âœ” Calling overloaded methods with different argument types and observing the results.Jain (Deemed-to-be University) Dr. Sanjeev Kumar Mandal, Ph.D, M.C.A, B.C.A Dr Sagar Gulati

ğŸ’» Day 44: Multilevel Inheritance in Java (Grandparent â†’ Parent â†’ Child) ğŸ§¬ğŸ”„ What You Explored: âœ… The concept of multilevel inheritance, where a class (Child) inherits from another class (Parent), and that class (Parent) inherits from a third class (Grandparent). âœ… How multilevel inheritance creates a chain of class relationships, allowing subclasses to inherit behavior from multiple levels of the class hierarchy. âœ… Real-world example of multilevel inheritance (e.g., a Grandparent class, a Parent class, and a Child class, where the child inherits behavior from both the parent and the grandparent).ğŸ”¥ Why It Matters: Multilevel inheritance enables you to build more complex hierarchies of classes, allowing for a more structured and reusable design. It encourages the reuse of code at each level of the hierarchy while also enabling specialization and extension of functionality in subclasses. This makes the code more organized, easier to maintain, and scalable.ğŸ† What You Practiced: âœ” Creating a class hierarchy where a subclass inherits from another subclass (Grandparent â†’ Parent â†’ Child). âœ” Understanding how each subclass can access properties and methods of its parent and grandparent classes. âœ” Demonstrating method inheritance and overriding in a multilevel context (e.g., showGrandparent(), showParent(), showChild()). âœ” Understanding how Java resolves method calls through the chain of inheritance.Jain (Deemed-to-be University)Dr. Sanjeev Kumar Mandal, Ph.D, M.C.A, B.C.ADr Sagar Gulati

ğŸ’» Day 46: Throw Example in Java ğŸ§¬ğŸ”„ What You Explored: âœ… The concept of using the throw keyword to explicitly throw exceptions in Java. âœ… How to create custom error messages when throwing exceptions to handle specific conditions in your code. âœ… A real-world example of throwing an exception when an invalid input is provided, such as when checking a person's age and ensuring it meets a certain criteria (e.g., age should be 18 or older).ğŸ”¥ Why It Matters: Using the throw keyword helps enforce rules and conditions in your code. When certain conditions are not met (like an invalid age), you can trigger an exception, allowing you to handle these errors appropriately. ğŸ’» Day 45: Method Overloading in SimpleMath ğŸ§¬ğŸ”„ What You Explored: âœ… The concept of method overloading, where you define multiple methods with the same name but different parameter types or number of parameters within the same class. âœ… How method overloading allows the same operation to be performed on different data types (e.g., int vs. double), providing flexibility and readability in the code. âœ… Real-world example of method overloading (e.g., a SimpleMath class with overloaded add(), sub(), and div() methods to handle both integer and floating-point numbers).ğŸ”¥ Why It Matters: Method overloading improves the versatility of your methods and makes your code more intuitive. Instead of creating multiple method names for similar operations, you can use the same method name with different parameters, keeping your code cleaner and easier to maintain. It helps you handle multiple scenarios with a single logical method name.ğŸ† What You Practiced: âœ” Creating overloaded methods with the same name but different parameter types (e.g., int vs. double). âœ” Understanding how Java resolves method calls based on the number and type of arguments passed. âœ” Demonstrating method overloading with arithmetic operations like addition, subtraction, and division. âœ” Calling overloaded methods with different argument types and observing the results.Jain (Deemed-to-be University) Dr. Sanjeev Kumar Mandal, Ph.D, M.C.A, B.C.A Dr Sagar Gulati

ğŸ’» Day 44: Multilevel Inheritance in Java (Grandparent â†’ Parent â†’ Child) ğŸ§¬ğŸ”„ What You Explored: âœ… The concept of multilevel inheritance, where a class (Child) inherits from another class (Parent), and that class (Parent) inherits from a third class (Grandparent). âœ… How multilevel inheritance creates a chain of class relationships, allowing subclasses to inherit behavior from multiple levels of the class hierarchy. âœ… Real-world example of multilevel inheritance (e.g., a Grandparent class, a Parent class, and a Child class, where the child inherits behavior from both the parent and the grandparent).ğŸ”¥ Why It Matters: Multilevel inheritance enables you to build more complex hierarchies of classes, allowing for a more structured and reusable design. It encourages the reuse of code at each level of the hierarchy while also enabling specialization and extension of functionality in subclasses. This makes the code more organized, easier to maintain, and scalable.ğŸ† What You Practiced: âœ” Creating a class hierarchy where a subclass inherits from another subclass (Grandparent â†’ Parent â†’ Child). âœ” Understanding how each subclass can access properties and methods of its parent and grandparent classes. âœ” Demonstrating method inheritance and overriding in a multilevel context (e.g., showGrandparent(), showParent(), showChild()). âœ” Understanding how Java resolves method calls through the chain of inheritance.Jain (Deemed-to-be University)Dr. Sanjeev Kumar Mandal, Ph.D, M.C.A, B.C.ADr Sagar Gulati

ğŸ’» Day 45: Method Overloading in SimpleMath ğŸ§¬ğŸ”„ What You Explored: âœ… The concept of method overloading, where you define multiple methods with the same name but different parameter types or number of parameters within the same class. âœ… How method overloading allows the same operation to be performed on different data types (e.g., int vs. double), providing flexibility and readability in the code. âœ… Real-world example of method overloading (e.g., a SimpleMath class with overloaded add(), sub(), and div() methods to handle both integer and floating-point numbers).ğŸ”¥ Why It Matters: Method overloading improves the versatility of your methods and makes your code more intuitive. Instead of creating multiple method names for similar operations, you can use the same method name with different parameters, keeping your code cleaner and easier to maintain. It helps you handle multiple scenarios with a single logical method name.ğŸ† What You Practiced: âœ” Creating overloaded methods with the same name but different parameter types (e.g., int vs. double). âœ” Understanding how Java resolves method calls based on the number and type of arguments passed. âœ” Demonstrating method overloading with arithmetic operations like addition, subtraction, and division. âœ” Calling overloaded methods with different argument types and observing the results.Jain (Deemed-to-be University) Dr. Sanjeev Kumar Mandal, Ph.D, M.C.A, B.C.A Dr Sagar Gulati

ğŸ’» Day 44: Multilevel Inheritance in Java (Grandparent â†’ Parent â†’ Child) ğŸ§¬ğŸ”„ What You Explored: âœ… The concept of multilevel inheritance, where a class (Child) inherits from another class (Parent), and that class (Parent) inherits from a third class (Grandparent). âœ… How multilevel inheritance creates a chain of class relationships, allowing subclasses to inherit behavior from multiple levels of the class hierarchy. âœ… Real-world example of multilevel inheritance (e.g., a Grandparent class, a Parent class, and a Child class, where the child inherits behavior from both the parent and the grandparent).ğŸ”¥ Why It Matters: Multilevel inheritance enables you to build more complex hierarchies of classes, allowing for a more structured and reusable design. It encourages the reuse of code at each level of the hierarchy while also enabling specialization and extension of functionality in subclasses. This makes the code more organized, easier to maintain, and scalable.ğŸ† What You Practiced: âœ” Creating a class hierarchy where a subclass inherits from another subclass (Grandparent â†’ Parent â†’ Child). âœ” Understanding how each subclass can access properties and methods of its parent and grandparent classes. âœ” Demonstrating method inheritance and overriding in a multilevel context (e.g., showGrandparent(), showParent(), showChild()). âœ” Understanding how Java resolves method calls through the chain of inheritance.Jain (Deemed-to-be University)Dr. Sanjeev Kumar Mandal, Ph.D, M.C.A, B.C.ADr Sagar Gulati

ğŸ’» Day 43: Single Inheritance in Java ğŸ§¬ğŸ”„ What You Explored: âœ… The concept of single inheritance, where a subclass inherits properties and methods from a single superclass. âœ… How single inheritance allows you to create a hierarchy of classes, enabling code reuse and modularity. âœ… Real-world example of single inheritance (e.g., an Animal superclass and a Dog subclass where the dog inherits common behaviors from the animal).ğŸ”¥ Why It Matters: Single inheritance makes code more manageable by promoting reuse. By inheriting common features from a parent class, subclasses donâ€™t need to repeat code, which simplifies maintenance and makes your code more organized. It also allows for extending the behavior of a class without modifying the original code, promoting scalability.ğŸ† What You Practiced: âœ” Creating a superclass with common properties and methods. âœ” Implementing a subclass that inherits and extends the functionality of the superclass. âœ” Overriding methods in the subclass to customize behavior (e.g., animalâ€™s generic behavior vs. dogâ€™s specific behavior). âœ” Understanding the inheritance flow and how a subclass inherits fields and methods from its superclass.Let me know if you'd like a detailed example or if you have any questions!Jain (Deemed-to-be University) Dr. Sanjeev Kumar Mandal, Ph.D, M.C.A, B.C.ADr Sagar Gulati

ğŸ’» Day 45: Method Overloading in SimpleMath ğŸ§¬ğŸ”„ What You Explored: âœ… The concept of method overloading, where you define multiple methods with the same name but different parameter types or number of parameters within the same class. âœ… How method overloading allows the same operation to be performed on different data types (e.g., int vs. double), providing flexibility and readability in the code. âœ… Real-world example of method overloading (e.g., a SimpleMath class with overloaded add(), sub(), and div() methods to handle both integer and floating-point numbers).ğŸ”¥ Why It Matters: Method overloading improves the versatility of your methods and makes your code more intuitive. Instead of creating multiple method names for similar operations, you can use the same method name with different parameters, keeping your code cleaner and easier to maintain. It helps you handle multiple scenarios with a single logical method name.ğŸ† What You Practiced: âœ” Creating overloaded methods with the same name but different parameter types (e.g., int vs. double). âœ” Understanding how Java resolves method calls based on the number and type of arguments passed. âœ” Demonstrating method overloading with arithmetic operations like addition, subtraction, and division. âœ” Calling overloaded methods with different argument types and observing the results.Jain (Deemed-to-be University) Dr. Sanjeev Kumar Mandal, Ph.D, M.C.A, B.C.A Dr Sagar Gulati
